Thus have I heard:
Once the World-Honored One was at Vulture Peak in RÄjagá¹›ha, together with a great assembly of 1,250 bhiká¹£us.
There was also an assembly of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, with Maitreya Bodhisattva at the head.
At that time, after the World-Honored One had observed ÅšÄriputra, he said to the bhiká¹£us:
If there is a bhiká¹£u who can understand the twelve links of dependent origination, he is said to see the Dharma;
Having seen this Dharma, he is said to see the Buddha.
After the World-Honored One had spoken thus, he remained silent.
At that time, ÅšÄriputra thought like this:
Now my World-Honored One has spoken this Dharma.ğŸ”½What is the meaning?
How can it be understood?
He then went to where Maitreya Bodhisattva was. When they arrived, they saw each other and used soft words to greet each other. They then sat down below a large rock with Maitreya Bodhisattva.
At that time, ÅšÄriputra said to Maitreya,
The World-Honored One has now spoken the ÅšÄri ÅšÄraman Sutra to the bhiká¹£us, saying:
'If the bhiká¹£us can see the twelve links of dependent origination, this is called seeing the Dharma;
Having seen this Dharma, it is called seeing the Buddha.'
Bodhisattva!
I do not understand this meaning now.
What are called the twelve links of dependent origination?
What is called the Dharma?
What is called the Buddha?
Please explain it briefly, Bodhisattva!
At that time, Maitreya Bodhisattva said to Venerable ÅšÄriputra,
The TathÄgata, the Dharma King, who is endowed with omniscience, speaks the profound and subtle Dharma according to the circumstances.
You now ask me, and I will now explain it briefly.
ÅšÄriputra!
As the World-Honored One said:
If there are bhiká¹£us who can see through the twelve links of dependent origination, this is called seeing the Dharma;
If one sees this Dharma, it is called seeing the Buddha.
ÅšÄriputra!

The twelve links of dependent origination are as follows: ignorance conditions formations, formations condition consciousness, consciousness conditions name-and-form, name-and-form conditions the six sense bases, the six sense bases condition contact, contact conditions feeling, feeling conditions craving, craving conditions clinging, clinging conditions becoming, becoming conditions birth, birth conditions old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress;
In this way, birth gives rise to the great mass of suffering.
ÅšÄriputra!

The cessation of ignorance is the cessation of volitional formations, the cessation of volitional formations is the cessation of consciousness, the cessation of consciousness is the cessation of name-and-form, the cessation of name-and-form is the cessation of the six sense bases, the cessation of the six sense bases is the cessation of contact, the cessation of contact is the cessation of feeling, the cessation of feeling is the cessation of craving, the cessation of craving is the cessation of clinging, the cessation of clinging is the cessation of existence, the cessation of existence is the cessation of birth, the cessation of birth is the cessation of old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, dejection, and anguish;
in this way, the cessation of this entire great mass of suffering occurs.
ÅšÄriputra!
The World-Honored One has thus explained the twelve links of dependent arising.
ÅšÄriputra said:
What is called the Dharma?
The Bodhisattva said:
The noble eightfold path is called the Dharma, namely right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration.
ÅšÄriputra!
The fruition of these eightfold paths is nirvÄá¹‡a, therefore the World-Honored One has briefly explained it as the Dharma.
ÅšÄriputra said:
What is meant by 'Buddha'?
The Bodhisattva said:
If one knows all dharmas, that is called 'Buddha.'
In this way, attaining the eye of holy wisdom, seeing the factors of enlightenment, one then realizes the Dharma body.
Furthermore, how does one see the twelve links of dependent arising?

As taught by the Buddha:ğŸ”½'If a person always sees these twelve links of dependent arising as unborn, unceasing, uncreated, unconditioned, ungrasped, unattached, as they are, non-inverted, tranquil, fearless, of great sages, inexhaustible, and completely devoid of intrinsic nature, if one sees in this way, that person sees the Dharma;

If one is able to always see in this way, as unborn, unceasing, uncreated, unconditioned, ungrasped, unattached, as they are, non-inverted, tranquil, fearless, of great sages, inexhaustible, and as seeing the Dharma devoid of intrinsic nature, that person sees the unsurpassed Dharma body.
The Buddha is one who has attained the right Dharma, right knowledge, and the cessation of samadhi.
Furthermore, Shariputra said:
For what reason is it called the twelve links of dependent origination?
The Bodhisattva said:
It is called the twelve links of dependent origination because there are causes and conditions.
Shariputra!
This Dharma is neither a cause nor a condition, nor is it not a cause or condition, and yet it arises from conditions.
The Son now briefly explains its characteristics.
Whether the Tathagata appears in the world or not, this Dharma of dependent origination always abides, is equal, true, and not false, because it is the true Dharma, free from inversion.
Moreover, Shariputra!
Such dependent origination is divided into two meanings.
What are the two?
One is from causes, the other is from conditions.
These two meanings are divided into internal and external.

The external conditions that arise from causes are as follows: from seeds sprouts arise, from sprouts stems arise, from stems branches and leaves arise, from branches and leaves flowers and fruits arise.
If there were no seeds, sprouts would not arise, and even flowers and fruits would not exist.
If there are seeds, sprouts, stems, and even flowers and fruits will all exist.
ÅšÄriputra!
Those seeds do not think:
'I can give rise to sprouts.'
Sprouts also do not think:
'I can give rise to stems.'
In this way, even flowers do not think:
'I can give rise to fruits.'
Fruits also do not think:
'I can arise from flowers.'
In this way, the external causes and conditions that arise from causes can be seen.
Moreover, ÅšÄriputra!
The external causes and conditions that arise from conditions refer to the combination of the six elements.
What are the six elements?
Namely, the earth element, water element, fire element, wind element, space element, and time element.

The earth element can provide stability, the water element can provide moisture, the fire element can provide warmth, the wind element can provide movement, the space element can provide unobstructedness, and the time element can provide completion.
In this way, when the six elements come together, seeds can produce sprouts, seedlings, flowers, and fruits, all complete.
If any one of the six elements is not present, the seed will not grow, and even the flowers and fruits will be unobtainable.
However, each of the six elements is without self. The earth does not say:
I can provide stability.
Water also does not say:
I can provide moisture.
Fire also does not say:
I can provide warmth.
Wind also does not say:
I can provide movement.
Space also does not say:
I can provide unobstructedness.
Time also does not say:ğŸ”½I can provide completion.
'I can accomplish it.'
However, the seed does not say:
'I can produce the sprout.'
The sprout also does not say:
'I arise from various conditions.'

That which is produced by the sprout and so forth is not self-made, not made by another, not made by both self and other together, not transformed by the Lord of Creation, not transformed by time, not produced by conditions, not produced by a single thing, and not produced without a cause.
However, from earth, water, fire, wind, space, time, seeds, flowers, and fruits, that which is produced arises neither from that nor from something else, because it is not completely destroyed.
This external dependent arising has five meanings.
What are the five?
Namely, not permanent, not discontinuous, although extinguished it is not exhausted, few causes and many effects, and mutually serving as objects.
What is meant by not permanent?
Namely, the seed and the sprout have different names.
What is meant by not discontinuous?
It means that from seeds there are sprouts, and sprouts give rise to branches and leaves.
Why is it that although extinguished, it is not exhausted?
Although extinguished means that the seeds are destroyed, appearing to be extinguished;
Not exhausted means that the seeds are transmitted and give rise to sprouts.
Why is it that from few causes, many fruits are produced?
It means that a single seed is the cause, and the fruits are abundant and manifold.
Why is it that they serve as objects for each other?
It means that because of the seeds, there are sprouts, up to flowers and fruits, which resemble each other in a continuous chain and again become seeds.
Furthermore, what are the twelve internal conditions?
These twelve conditions have two meanings.
What are the two?
They are: first, arising from causes, and second, arising from conditions.
What is meant by arising from causes?
From ignorance, there arises activity, up to birth, old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, suffering, and distress.
If there were no ignorance, activity would also not be established, up to no old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, suffering, and distress.
Yet that ignorance does not think:
'I can give rise to action.'
Action also does not think:
'I arise from ignorance.'
Up to birth also does not think:
'I can give rise to old age, death, worry, sorrow, suffering, and distress.'
Old age and death, etc. also do not think:
'I arise from birth.'
This is called the characteristic of arising from causes.
What is meant by arising from conditions?
It means that the six elements come together as conditions.
What are the six?
Namely, earth, water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness.
When these six elements come together, this is called arising from conditions.
What is meant by the earth element?
It refers to the solidity of the body, this is called the earth element.
If the body is moist, this is called the water element;
If the body is warm, this is called the fire element;
If there is inhalation and exhalation, this is called the wind element;
If the body is unobstructed, this is called the space element.
Eye consciousness up to the eighth consciousness, this is called the consciousness realm.
In this way, the six elements are born from the combination of conditions.
However, the earth element does not think:
'I can make things solid.'
The water element also does not think:
'I can make things moist.'
The fire element also does not think:
'I can make things warm.'
The wind element also does not think:
'I can make the in-breath and out-breath.'
The space element also does not think:
'I can make things unobstructed.'
Consciousness also does not think:
'I can bring about completion.'
The body also does not think:
'I am born from various conditions.'
However, without various conditions, the body also does not arise.
That earth element is without self, without person, without sentient being, without life, neither male nor female, and also without self and without other;

up to the elements of water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness, are also without self, without person, without sentient beings, without life, neither male nor female, and also without self and other.

Moreover, if one has a single thought regarding these six elements, such as the thought of an ordinary being, the thought of permanence, the thought of reality, the thought of longevity, the thought of happiness, the thought of self, the thought of person, the thought of sentient beings, the thought of life, or the thought of wriggling creatures, due to lack of wisdom, one has such various thoughts. Therefore, it is called ignorance.
Because of ignorance, greed and hatred arise.
Ignorance conditions formations, and formations are also like this, attached to false names, giving rise to various false thoughts called consciousness;
consciousness gives rise to name-and-form;
name-and-form gives rise to the six sense bases;
the six sense bases give rise to contact;ğŸ”½because of contact, there is feeling;
because of feeling, there is craving;ğŸ”½because of craving, there is grasping;
because of grasping, there is becoming;
Because there is existence, it can give rise to the subsequent aggregates, which is called birth;
After birth, there is decay and change, which is old age;
Because the aggregates decay and disintegrate, it is death;
Because of ignorance, one gives rise to sorrow, lamentation, suffering, and distress.
Moreover, because the mass of various sufferings oppresses the body and mind, one dwells in great darkness, which is called ignorance;
To create is action;
To discriminate is consciousness;
To establish characteristics is name-and-form;
The six sense bases are the six sense bases;
To encounter objects is contact;
To experience pleasure and pain is feeling;
Hunger and thirst is craving;
Pursuing is grasping;
To give rise to karma again is becoming;
The arising of the subsequent aggregates is birth;
The ripening of the aggregates is old age;
Their destruction is death;ğŸ”½Anxiety is sorrow;
Distress is lamentation;
Various sufferings are suffering;
Disturbance is distress.
Moreover, to turn away from truth is to take falsehood as true, and to take wrong views as right views. Because of this lack of wisdom, it is called ignorance.
There are three kinds of action, namely, meritorious action, demeritorious action, and unvarying action.

Performing meritorious action leads to the knowledge of meritorious action, performing demeritorious action leads to the knowledge of demeritorious action, performing unvarying action leads to the knowledge of unvarying action.
In this way, up to old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress.

These twelve conditions each have their own causes and effects, are neither permanent nor annihilated, are neither conditioned nor apart from conditioned, are not mental phenomena, are not exhaustible phenomena, are not ceasing phenomena, and are inherently existent from the beginning, and what is produced is not cut off.
It is like a river, flowing without interruption.
At that time, Maitreya Bodhisattva again said to ÅšÄriputra:
Those twelve conditions are further increased by four conditions, namely, ignorance, craving, karma, and consciousness, and so forth.
That seed of consciousness takes its own nature as the cause, takes karma as the ground, and is covered by the afflictions of ignorance and craving, and the seed of consciousness arises.
That karma is the ground for consciousness, craving is the moisture for consciousness, and ignorance covers consciousness, enabling it to be accomplished.
That karma does not think:
'I can provide the ground for the seed of consciousness.'
Craving also does not think:
'I can provide the moisture for the seed of consciousness.'
Ignorance also does not think:
'I can provide the covering for the seed of consciousness.'
For this reason, the seed of consciousness is accomplished.
Consciousness also does not think:
'I am born from various conditions.'
Furthermore, karma is the ground for consciousness, craving is the moisture, and ignorance covers the seed, which then grows in the mother's womb, becoming the sprout of name-and-form.

That sprout of name-and-form is not self-produced, not produced by another, not produced by both self and other together, not produced by an almighty being, not produced by time transforming, not produced from a fundamental cause, and not produced without causes and conditions.
This dharma truly arises from the combination of parents and various conditions.
However, the sprout of name-and-form has no owner, no acceptance or rejection, and its nature is like the illusion of emptiness.
Furthermore, there are five kinds of causes and conditions that give rise to eye consciousness.
What are the five?
Namely, eye, form, light, space, and mental activity.
Based on these five conditions, eye consciousness arises.

The eye serves as the basis, form is what is grasped, light provides illumination, space provides unobstruction, and mental activity gives rise to various functions. For these reasons, eye consciousness can arise.
If the conditions such as eye, form, light, space, and mental activity do not come together, eye consciousness will not arise.
However, the eye does not think:
'I can serve as the basis for eye consciousness.'
Form also does not think:
'I can cause consciousness to grasp.'
Light also does not think:
'I can cause consciousness to have insight.'
Space also does not think:
'I can cause consciousness to be unobstructed.'
The mind also does not think:
'I can cause consciousness to arise and act.'
Consciousness also does not think:
'I can arise from various conditions.'
However, eye consciousness truly arises from the combination of various conditions.
The arising of all faculties in sequence is also like this.
Furthermore, there is no dharma that goes from this world to the next world, but only the results of karma, causes and conditions, and what arises from delusion.
It is like a bright mirror reflecting a face, with the face appearing in the mirror, but in reality no face enters the mirror. It is because of delusion and conditions that it appears.

It is also like the full moon high in the sky, forty-two thousand yojanas above the ground, with its reflection appearing in many waters. The moon does not disappear from there and reappear in the water. It also appears because of delusion and conditions.
It is also like when one obtains firewood, the fire burns, and when the firewood is exhausted, it goes out.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!

There are no sentient beings who go from this world to the next world, nor does the next world come to this world, but it is only through the formation of karma that the seeds of consciousness are produced everywhere.
Relying on the mother's womb, the sprout of name-and-form is born.

This principle of causes and conditions is originally without an owner, without a self, without grasping, and without abandoning, like empty space, like an illusion, without any real dharma, yet the retribution for good and evil karma is not lost.
Moreover, the twelve links are also explained through five things.
What are the five?
Namely, impermanence, non-discontinuity, non-extinction, few causes and many effects, and similarity.
What is meant by impermanence?
It means that when this aggregate ceases, that aggregate arises. Cessation is not arising, and arising is not cessation. Because arising and cessation are different, it is called impermanence.
What is meant by non-discontinuity?
It is like a scale, when one side goes up, the other side goes down. This ceases and that arises, so it is said to be uninterrupted.
Why is it said to be unceasing?
Because the causes and actions created in the realm of sentient beings are all unceasing.
Why is it said to have few causes and many fruits?
Because the causes and actions one creates are like working in a field, if one concentrates one's mind and exerts effort, one will reap abundant fruits.
Why is it said to be similar?
Because the causes and actions one creates do not result in different retributions, it is said to be similar.
Furthermore, ÅšÄriputra!
As the Buddha has said:
'If one is able to contemplate the twelve links of dependent arising, it is called correct contemplation and correct wisdom.'
What is meant by correct contemplation and correct wisdom?
It means contemplating what arises in the three times of past, future, and present, not forming the notion of existence or non-existence, coming from nowhere and going nowhere.

This is the attainment of the Dharma of non-arising and non-cessation.
ÅšÄriputra!

This person will attain the perfection of the acceptance of the Dharma. The TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened One, the One Perfect in Knowledge and Conduct, the Well-Gone One, the Knower of the World, the Incomparable Leader, the Trainer of Men, the Teacher of Gods and Men, the Buddha, the World-Honored One, will give him the prophecy of supreme perfect enlightenment.

At that time, after Maitreya Bodhisattva had spoken this Dharma, Venerable ÅšÄriputra, as well as the devas, humans, asuras, gandharvas, and others, joyfully accepted it with faith, bowed their heads, and withdrew.
